description: From Middle English blere, related to Low German bleeroged (“bleareyed”), Middle High German blerre (“double vision”), German Blerre (“double vision”). Perhaps also related to blur.

adjectives.description: blear (comparative more blear, superlative most blear)

entries.meaning: (of eyes or vision) Dim, unclear from water or rheum.
examples: The Devil, now disguised as a half-wit peasant to Lars-Goren’s left, stood grinning, his blear eyes glittering.

entries.meaning: Causing or caused by dimness of sight.

description: From Middle English bleren, from Old English blerian.

verbs.description: blear (third-person singular simple present blears, present participle blearing, simple past and past participle bleared)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To be blear; to have blear eyes; to look or gaze with blear eyes.
examples: The crowder of that barb’rous nation,

entries.meaning: (transitive, of the eyes or eyesight) To make blurred or dim.
examples: I smile to see how you devise,
New masking nets my eies to bleare:
your self you cannot so disguise:
But as you are, you must appeare.

entries.meaning: (transitive, of an image) To blur, make blurry.
examples: When winter blears bleakly the forest,
And the water binds gray to its blue,
Safe and sound in her covert I leave her,
Till spring calls again my canoe.
